isis.stitle: International® MaxxForce™ 7 Engine Service Manual - Power Cylinders - Removal - Preliminary Checks

note.para: Evaluate piston protrusion before removing any piston and connecting rod assemblies. This will help identify bent or twisted connecting rods.
Before checking piston protrusion, make sure upper crankcase assembly deck surface is flat and level. See Crankcase Inspection .
Piston protrusion readings are done at 3 and 9 o'clock positions. These positions are in line with piston pin, eliminating rocking movement of piston at any other position of measurement.

step1.para: Check piston protrusion above upper crankcase assembly as follows:

step2.para:
Zero dial indicator with magnetic base
on upper crankcase assembly deck surface.
Position dial indicator tip over piston head at 3 o'clock position.
Rotate crankshaft in direction of normal rotation to raise piston to its maximum outward protrusion at cylinder Top Dead Center (TDC). Read this maximum protrusion on dial indicator.
Reposition dial indicator tip on piston head at 9 o'clock position.
Rotate crankshaft to raise the piston to its maximum protrusion. Read maximum protrusion on dial indicator.
Average the two readings. Replace piston and connecting rod if protrusion is outside specifications .

figure.caption: Side clearance check for connecting rod and cap

step1.para:
Use a feeler gauge
to check connecting rod side clearance as follows:

step2.para: Pry apart a pair of connecting rods on a crankshaft rod journal. Insert largest possible feeler gauge between connecting rods to check side clearance.
Repeat for each pair of connecting rods on each crankshaft rod journal and compare with specification .

note.para: Lack of clearance could indicate a damaged connecting rod or a connecting rod bearing out of position. Excessive clearance may require replacement of connecting rods or crankshaft assembly. Correct as required.
